text: @2351onthelist < something some people are, and it occurs in all groups of humans, so it isn't even something you *can* import anywhere.

@2351onthelist < made, but it's not like we're only doing this because we saw other countries doing it and thought "ooh, that looks good!".

Or is it being trans that you're talking about being imported? That's also not the case: trans people have always been here. Being trans is just >

@2351onthelist < bit odd to label a change in the system behind issuing certain paperwork a "perversion". And anyway, while other countries do have similar policies, this isn't being imported: what other countries do provides useful evidence for what will likely happen when this change is >

@2351onthelist < to care what other countries do.

And what perversion? Being trans? That's not a perversion. There's nothing wrong with being trans. What are you referring to being imported - making it easy to get a GRC? In which case, is *that* what you're calling the perversion? Seems a >

@2351onthelist Well, if you're going to assert (as Sodha does) that this policy will lead to bad outcomes, it seems relevant to examine other countries where similar policies have been implemented and see whether, in line with your assertion, the bad outcomes did indeed occur: in other words, >

@obsolete__units @aoirann @soniasodha < they have a GRC, then you have to treat them exactly like cis people of the same gender" or words to that effect.

Anyway, I'm glad you agree that a GRC doesn't grant an AMAB person access to women's spaces. So what's the problem with making them easy to get?

@obsolete__units @aoirann @soniasodha < count as a trans woman ("have the protected characteristic of gender reassignment") for the purposes of the act. And there is nothing anywhere that says those with a GRC should be treated differently from those without. In particular, Section 28 in Part 7 doesn't say "unless >

@obsolete__units @aoirann @soniasodha < doesn't say anything about any service providers having to exclude trans women from women's spaces if anyone comes along with an argument that it could be justified as a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim. Any service provider can choose to include trans women, >

@obsolete__units @aoirann @soniasodha < makes it clear that an exception to treating trans women the same as cis women (or trans men the same as cis men) *can* be made when it comes to single-sex services *provided it can be justified as a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim*. (Note that it absolutely >

@obsolete__units @aoirann @soniasodha You're right about it being the Equality, not Equalities Act - sorry for that mistake. (I've heard it called the Equalities Act so many times it's got into my head.)

You're also right that GRCs don't give AMAB people access to women's spaces. That was my point! Section 28 >
@obsolete__units @soniasodha < grant him access to any spaces. What's so awful about that? (And why would any cis person bother doing that in any case, even if it was really, really easy?)

@obsolete__units @soniasodha So, let's suppose a cis man does obtain a GRC that says he's a woman (or a cis woman obtains one that says she's a man, but you never seem so worried about that). Then... he'll be referred to as female on the paperwork if he gets married and when he dies. That's it. It doesn't >

@niceedin @obsolete__units @soniasodha <been living in the acquired gender but that there should be other ways too (in which case, isn't it rather unfair that anyone who's happy keeping their name has to do things that those who want to change their name don't have to?)

@niceedin @obsolete__units @soniasodha < change should be necessary (in which case my questions stand)? Or that you agree with the second person (in which case great)? Or that you think something else again should be required? Or that you think a name change should be one possible way of demonstrating that you've >

@niceedin @obsolete__units @soniasodha So, someone asked what living in the acquired gender meant, someone said changing your name e.g. on bills would do it, and someone else said just changing your pronouns would be enough. What's your point exactly? That you agree with the first person that *at least* a name >

@niceedin @obsolete__units @soniasodha < problem with trans people having non-gender-conforming names)? And what's wrong with a woman (or girl) having a name like Michael, or a man (or boy) having a name like Marion anyway?

@niceedin @obsolete__units @soniasodha < Or is this one of those things that is immoral but shouldn't be illegal (in which case, why make it a legal requirement for trans people wanting a GRC to have a name that's seen as matching their gender)? Or are you actually fine with that (in which case, again, what's your >

@niceedin @obsolete__units @soniasodha < commonly given to people of their gender? The first girls called Ashley, Taylor, Cameron, Allison, Jamie, or Madison were all named at a time when those names were overwhelmingly seen as "boys' names". Should their parents have been legally barred from giving their daughters >

@niceedin @obsolete__units @soniasodha < about people who go by Sam or Alex or Chris - if they change their full name from Samuel to Samantha or Alexandra to Alexander or Christopher to Christine does that count even if no-one ever actually calls them that?

In any case, why do people have to go by names that are >

@niceedin @obsolete__units @soniasodha So, you're saying you think anyone who wants a GRC should be obliged to change their name? Does that even apply to people called things like Robin or Taylor or Cameron? How much of a change would you require - could a Leslie change to Lesley or is that still the same name? What >
@obsolete__units @soniasodha < to feel the same.)

@obsolete__units @soniasodha < people made sure applicants were actually doing that rather than taking their word for it? (Personally, while I'm against the requirement to "live as the acquired gender", I have no issue with people using the toilets that match their gender, but I wouldn't have expected you >

@obsolete__units @soniasodha < involves a requirement to live as the acquired gender, but for a considerably longer period), "living as the acquired gender" has generally been interpreted as meaning, among other things, using the toilets and changing rooms that match that gender. Are you sure you'd prefer >

@obsolete__units @soniasodha < should be issued unless a properly qualified and duly convened panel has actually verified that the sprungling of noofium has in fact taken place". Ok, then.

By the way, I wonder if you're aware that (fun fact!) under the current system (which, as Sodha mentions, also

@obsolete__units @soniasodha < knows what it is) by just lying and saying they did it. You think things would be at least slightly better if everyone getting a GRC was forced to actually do X, even though you don't know what X is. "People are just lying and saying they've sprungled noofium! No certificates >

@obsolete__units @soniasodha So let me get this straight. You agree that "nobody knows what living as the opposite sex means" (and possibly also with the point about this requirement reinforcing gender stereotypes). But you're also outraged that applicants could skip doing this thing (that nobody, >

@obsolete__units @aoirann @soniasodha < default be treated the same as a cis person of the same gender, and that service providers can choose to make an exception to that default only if they can justify it as a proportionate means of meeting a legitimate aim.

@obsolete__units @aoirann @soniasodha No, *you're* pretty confused if you think a GRC determines access to women's spaces. Or that the Equalities Act doesn't say that *any* trans person (with or without a GRC or diagnosis of gender dysphoria or having medically transitioned - in other words, self ID) must by >
@MargaretBluman @soniasodha We're not being "thrown down the river". This poses no threat to our safety, privacy, dignity, or rights, and plenty of us support this reform.
@AJPeace @soniasodha < from fraudulently getting one if you're cis.

@AJPeace @soniasodha Very much this. But also, this system *can't* be abused in the way Sodha et al. describe, because GRCs don't determine access to spaces. They just let (binary) trans people be recognised as the gender they are in paperwork when marrying and dying. There's nothing to be gained >
@fishpawz @Bennett_C_ @soniasodha < lots of women (maybe even a majority?) who fully support trans rights and understand they pose no threat to us.

@fishpawz @Bennett_C_ @soniasodha < with people phrasing things in such a way as to suggest that all women and girls (or even all cis women and girls) think the same way about this issue (usually that we're opposed to trans rights due to a belief they clash with our own). There are women with GC views, but also >

@fishpawz @Bennett_C_ @soniasodha I'm a woman in Scotland and I support this bill. I hope it passes. It doesn't affect us (cis women and girls), because a GRC doesn't determine access to women's spaces despite what you all seem to think. I'm fed up of people propagating false information about that, and also >

@soniasodha < surprising that you're against this; but hey, I'll take it. Welcome on board with being in favour with reforming the GRA to make it easier to get a GRC by doing away with the requirement for a period of living as the acquired gender, at least.

@soniasodha < the acquired gender for 3 months requires an increased level of dedication (and, for someone who isn't actually that gender, involves more inconvenience/hassle) than just needing to make an affirmation. (Similarly with the 3 month reflection period.) So it's a little >

@soniasodha < the acquired gender is still required (albeit for a reduced period) is as a sop towards people like you who are convinced predatory cis men will apply for GRCs to access women's spaces (even though access isn't determined by having a GRC or not): the idea is that living as >

@soniasodha < reforms happening at all (though, as mentioned, it would make sense as an attack on the exact details of the proposed reforms, being an argument for their going further).

This is also bizarre as a line of attack because, as I understand it, the reason a period of living in >

@soniasodha < requirement would make some sense as an attack on the initial introduction of GRCs, but it simply doesn't as an attack on proposed reforms that aren't bringing this in as a new element but are simply retaining it (and very slightly relaxing it) - at least, not as an attack on >

@soniasodha < away with that requirement, because the proposed reforms are an improvement in other aspects, and don't make things worse with regard to this element (and indeed improve things a bit here too in that at least the period this is required for is reduced). Taking issue with this >

@soniasodha < of other people who support the bill, agree with you that it is not clear what "living in the acquired gender" means and share your concerns about the possibility this may reinforce gender stereotypes. But we still want the bill to pass, even if we'd prefer a bill that did >

@soniasodha In addition, I find the point about time spent living in the acquired gender odd as an attack on the GRA reform bill, given that, as you mention, the current system requires living in the acquired gender for a considerably longer period. Don't get me wrong: I, along with plenty >
@soniasodha < consequences you predict for women's and girls' safety, privacy, and dignity. Do better.

@soniasodha This piece is rife with errors/inaccuracies, and makes it sound as though Sturgeon is boldly going where no jurisdiction has gone before, whereas in fact many countries have similar or less restrictive policies around their equivalent of GRCs, and are not facing the dire >
